title: Asda staff who refused to sign new contracts will lose their jobs on 3 November
text:

Asda workers who refused to sign the retailer's new employment terms will face the axe on November 3, as a wave of contract changes come into force.

Union GMB told Mirror Money it'll be those who "have second jobs" and "childcare responsibilities" that will suffer the most, after the US-owned supermarket issued an ultimatum to workers to sign up to contract changes or leave the company.

"Asda used to be a well-respected company where colleagues were proud to wear the Asda badge. This has changed and the change is not one for the better," union GMB said.

It comes as the trade union for staff members prepare to a march outside Asda’s head office in Leeds today to hand deliver thousands of customer letters to Asda’s CEO – Roger Burnley.

It'll be followed by a 28,000 strong petition demanding a further review of the clauses that staff told Mirror Money have left them feeling like prisoners.

(Image: Daily Record)

Asda workers who declined to sign the new contracts were put on 12 weeks' notice earlier this year.

The protest is in relation to grocer’s decision to issue their workforce with dismissal letters advising them they will be sacked if they refused to sign a "one-sided punitive" new contract.

"Asda Colleagues are to be sacked upon 3 November due to them having second jobs, having childcare responsibilities and wishing to have a personal life," GMB said.

But a statement from Asda today said comments about "colleagues being sacked due to commitments outside work are untrue".

This period comes to a close on 3 November - when those who've not yet signed, will face termination.

A covering letter provided by Keith Dixon, GMB regional organiser states: "During discussions with those customers GMB London Region spoke at length upon the way in which Asda Colleagues were being threatened with the sack and are having your ‘Contract 6’ forced upon them.

"A contract as you know is flexible purely for Asda’s benefit.

"This flexibility will clearly provide financial savings for the business and is one of the key parts which the business failed to discuss or disclose during the consultation period. This we feel is underhand and deceives your colleagues.

"Your customers were disgusted with the way your loyal colleagues are being treated and as such have willingly signed the letters and agreed for them to be presented to you.

"Most of your customers have included a home address or an email address for you to respond directly. The rest have requested that a response is forwarded to my office."

"You have the power and the authority to correct the direction the business has driven Asda to; however, you have an uphill battle to win back the respect and trust your employees had of Asda."

Mirror Money put GMB's comments to Asda - which responded with claims that the changes will leave 100,000 workers better off.

"Whilst we respect the right of the GMB to express its views, the comments from them this morning around Asda colleagues being sacked due to commitments outside work are untrue," An Asda spokesperson said.

"This change represents an investment of over £80m and an increase in real pay for over 100000 of our hourly paid colleagues.

"Throughout the consultation process on these changes we have taken colleague concerns and feedback from colleague representatives on board and have been clear that we understand our colleagues have responsibilities outside of work and we will always help them balance these with their work life.

"We have been clear that we don’t want any of our colleagues to leave us and whilst the vast majority of colleagues have chosen to sign the new contract, we continue to have conversations with those who have chosen not to, to try and understand their concerns.

"It is vital that we make sure we are prepared to adapt to the demands of our market. Change is never easy, but we are determined that Asda remains a sustainable business for its customers and colleagues – now and in the future."
description: A long-running dispute over the Walmart-owned supermarket's new employment terms will come to an end next month when those who refused to sign will have their contracts terminated
